MCI

MCI

The brief

MCI stands for "measure of industrial mail" in French and represents a service built by the French mail services to monitor their performances towards others Europeans competitors and ensure that they provide a great quality of services to their clients.

GIDE is a French software development company based in Nantes and specialized in building tool for the market research industry.

How it works

A user logs into the MCI app or website and reports when they have received a special kind of mail, then they are rewarded with virtual money they can spend on a dedicated online store. Of course, the service offers a lot more than this, but those are the key functionalities.

Why?

The app was barely usable and the website developed more than 8 years at a time where user experience was for to be as developed as today. Many UX problems were impacting the experience provided to the users and because the end goal is to collect precise data any loss in users could result in il lower quality statistics.

Research

Audit

I started by doing a UX audit of the old website and app. It went really fast for the app as it was barely usable and everything had to be changed. The website was a bit more complicated.

After studying many users journey through the app it appears that some key functionalities were hidden in complicated navigation or badly named call to action.

Methodology

I introduced the object-oriented UX methodology (OOUX) to the team and we started to scaffold the structure of the service. Combined with Scrumban for team organization this methodology allowed us to quickly build meaningful and well-organized pages.

Daily meetings allowed each member of the team to keep track of the progress made by the others, we discussed the problems encountered and tried to solve them together.

Wireframes

Wireframes helped us organize all the component described with the OOUX methodology. As the pages started to appear we had to design and describe new components for UI, navigation or even just to make the content more organized. In the end, we started to describe the behavior of each component and each block in the pages.

Production

After validation of the wireframes and user flows by the client we started the production a high fidelity prototype in Adobe XD. The feedback from users helped us to fine-tune some details in the UX.

UI design

The client also asked for a redesign of the look of the app. It had to feel more modern with scarifying usability and habits of the users.

Colors

The colors chosen are based on the one used by the French mail services in their branding, but to keep color contrast ok in all places I had to

Empty states

We used empty states to provide extra information to the user. I crafted some illustration in order to make the app look a bit more friendly to the end user.

Animations

As the app had to run smoothly on all devices the use of animation was restricted to the most meaningful interactions where it was providing extra information to the user about what was happening.

Development

PWA

In order to cut the need to maintain a different app for each os, we had chosen to make a fusion of the mobile app and of the website into a single progressive web application. This would provide a unified responsive experience to all users while lowering the cost and time needed to maintain the system.

Vue.js

In order to provide native-like experience but with web technologies we used Vue.js as our base framework. It allowed us to re-use the component hierarchy built with the OOUX methodology at the beginning of the user research.

The word of the end

This was really the best project I worked on during my internship at GIDE. It allowed me to experiment with different new methodologies and to learn their benefits and limits. The work I did has been pushed live to real users and we had excellent feedback from the client.
